What is Biology?.q: A scientist observes that a structure can move, respond to stimuli, and reproduce. What characteristic confirms it is living rather than a sophisticated machine?

A biologist must choose between experimenting on a whole organism versus cell cultures. What is the main advantage of studying the whole organism?
What process do ALL living things perform to convert nutrients into usable energy?
In a controlled experiment, you change the temperature while studying enzyme activity. Everything else stays the same. What do we call the factors that stay the same?
A hypothesis states 'If plants receive more sunlight, then they will grow taller.' What type of variable is 'plant height'?
What characteristic of life explains why you sweat when you're hot and shiver when you're cold?
When organizing life from smallest to largest, what comes after organism?
What fundamental unit of life was discovered by Robert Hooke when examining cork under a microscope?
A theory in science is best described as what?
answers: Can be modified with new data

What is Biology?.q: What tool would give you the highest magnification when observing bacteria?

What is the basic unit that makes up all living things according to Cell Theory?
When making observations in an experiment, what type uses measurements and numbers?
What process allows species to change over time and become better suited to their environment?

Biochemistry.q: An ionic bond forms between two atoms. What is the fundamental process that occurs with their electrons?
answers: One atom loses, one gains electrons

Biochemistry.q: A student tests a food sample. Biuret test turns purple and Sudan IV turns red, but Benedict's and iodine tests are negative. Which macromolecules are present?
What describes the primary structure of a protein?

An enzyme's function is destroyed when exposed to high heat. What specifically has been altered?
Carbon can form 4 covalent bonds. What property of carbon allows this?
A solution has a pH of 3. What is the concentration of H+ ions compared to a pH of 6?
What type of macromolecule is an enzyme?

What bond connects amino acids together in a protein?

What process breaks down polymers into monomers by adding water?
DNA and RNA are examples of which type of macromolecule?
Saturated fats have no double bonds between carbons. What state are they typically in at room temperature?
What happens to reaction rate when you increase enzyme concentration (assuming excess substrate)?

What type of transport requires energy (ATP) to move substances across a membrane?
